content: In a proof I'm working on, I have a point x in a first-countable, locally path-connected space and want to obtain a sequence of nested path-connected neighbourhoods that form a basis at that point. Mathematically, this is easy: pick any countable neighbourhood basis, turn it into a nested sequence by taking partial intersections, and then make those path-connected by restricting to a path component each. I could probably do this construction from scratch, but still wondered if there is some API to make the process easier.

To my surprise, I didn't find anything about neighbourhood bases as nested sequences in mathlib at all. docs#FirstCountableTopology doesn't have a lot of API, and is defined in terms of docs#Filter.IsCountablyGenerated; for that, I couldn't find any helpful API either. I also know of docs#partialSups and docs#Set.Accumulate which seem relevant, but couldn't find infimum/intersection counterparts.

Is there something I'm missing, or have sequences of neighbourhoods like that just not come up a lot of mathlib? And what even would be the best way of stating the lemma that first-countable locally path-connected spaces admit sequences of nested path-connected neighbourhoods like I want?

I just found docs#Filter.exists_antitone_basis, which seems pretty close to what I need; I didn't think of searching for the keyword antitone earlier. I'll try using it in my proof tomorrow and see how it goes.
Ben Eltschig has marked this topic as resolved.
